content.intro:
The second largest city in France, Marseille is renowned for its high-quality urban development and constant creativity.

Marseille, the oldest city in France, was founded 2,600 years ago by Greek merchants and mariners. Today, it boasts a population of over one million: a population proud of their history and heritage. Spread over 57km of coastline, with 24 calanques (inlets), the city sets records for sunshine: up to 300 days a year.

The visitor wanders through 26 centuries here, from Saint-Laurent hilltop, occupied since ancient times, to the Saint-Jean and Saint-Nicolas forts encircling the port, not to mention the churches and old streets, or the large architectural projects of the 21st century, such as the new Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations (Mucem).

You have to walk - be a flâneur - in Marseille to capture the richness of its heritage and the myriad colours of its diversity and multiculturalism.

Go to the old port and watch small fishing boats head out to sea and return. Visit the Panier, an authentic and popular neighbourhood of beautiful buildings, charming squares, and narrow streets. Climb up the Notre Dame de la Garde basilica, nicknamed the 'Good Mother', the guardian of sailors and fishermen, to admire the city in all its glory. Walk along the Prado beaches and contemplate the Calanques national park and its incredible local wildlife. Alternately, enjoy the same gorgeous scene from a different point of view: he sea! Sports enthusiasts will jump in a wetsuit and explore about a hundred diving spots around the area. Back on the land, go out for dinner in the spectacular dining establishments of a new generation of creative restaurateurs. Go shopping on rue Paradis in the Docks district. Life is good for the residents of this, the second largest city of France, and their warm smiles and singsong accents make your stay here pleasant and memorable. Oh, one more thing: do not leave the home of the “Radiant City” without trying the famous bouillabaisse, aioli, and fougasse.

The Marseille Centre Bompard La Corniche is a stylish and peaceful hotel in the fashionable Bompard district, on the heights of the Kennedy Corniche.

The four-star establishment enjoys an elegant and serene setting, surrounded by lush greenery. Not far from the city centre, this beautiful bourgeois estate is a romantic paradise, and the perfect base for sightseeing. Its tree-filled grounds and swimming pool are idyllic. The 50 rooms are decorated in a palette of honey, slate, and grey green, and feature refined furnishings accented by gentle lighting. They are spread across four gorgeous buildings nestled at the heart of the grounds, including one traditional Provençal farmhouse and a stunning bourgeois mansion, both of which are very well appointed.

The Albert Café restaurant is a retro and cosy spot for a meal by the fireplace in winter, or out on the large terrace in spring or summer. The bar area stays open till midnight, and is a pleasant place for a cocktail or a glass of wine.

content.title: La Mercerie weaves a link between food lovers and farmers

introduction.small: Forever linked to the Canebière, the emblematic Cat haberdashery made way for a bistro committed to promote the work of local farmers with its creative cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Mercerie weaves a link between food lovers and farmers

paragraphs.text:
Right where the Cat haberdashery stood, old institution of the Noailles district, you will now find a modern local bistro with a terrace in the shade of some olive trees. No more ribbons, buttons and balls of wool, only the name lasted as a tribute to the past. The atmosphere remains industrial with exposed concrete walls, a long chestnut counter and an aqua-tiled cuisine.

Three friends run the place, including English chef Harry Cummins. La Mercerie highlights regional farming through creative cooking that changes on a daily basis. For instance, you may be lucky enough to try the Mediterranean brill with broccoli and delicious candied kumquats, or the spare ribs with spelt, cabbage and burnt orange. The chef puts an emphasis on sourcing most of the products used. For those he cannot do so, he even decided to produce them himself, like bread and vinegars. This committed stance is also shared by Laura Vidal, awarded best Sommelier in 2020 by the Gault et Millau Guide. She arranged La Mercerie's wine list with wine makers who are also environmentally-inclined.

content.title: Friche La Belle de Mai, spearhead of Marseille culture

introduction.small: La Friche in the Belle de Mai neighbourhood is a Marseille hotspot for culture and performing arts, but also a skatepark and playful learning ground for children.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Friche La Belle de Mai, spearhead of Marseille culture

paragraphs.text:
With almost 400,000 visitors each year, over 100,000 sqm open to the public in the Belle de Mai neighbourhood of Marseille, La Friche has come a long way since it officially opened in 1992. Completely modernised, the 19th-century industrial site has been offered a new lease on life, turned towards culture. The former SEITA tobacco factory is now a lively place where artists perform in residence while visitors may bump into a street art exhibition, or practice a few moves on a board bought at the skateshop. Else, they can also have lunch on the terrace while immersed in the book straight out of the independent bookshop also located on the premises. And that is not all! You can also attend a play in one of the five venues, play a family game of basketball, try some yoga during a parent-child class and initiate a new generation to art forms through a playful course… La Friche evolves on a daily basis with new and upcoming projects. Young and old alike, painting, sculpture, music or sports enthusiast, everybody will find something to suit their taste!

content.title: Glorified seafood at Au Bout du Quai

introduction.small: After a visit to the Mucem or a stroll on the Old Port, food lovers usually stop at Au Bout du Quai to enjoy some seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Glorified seafood at Au Bout du Quai

paragraphs.text:
Facing the Old Port, with the Saint-Jean Fort and the abbey of Saint-Victor in your eyesight, the restaurant's setting is idyllic and yet totally preserved from the crowds. Seating on the terrace with a view of the Notre-Dame de la Garde basilica, the patrons at Au Bout du Quai ("At the far end of the dock" in English) take in the soft sunshine, sea breeze and gorgeous scenery before eyeing the menu. Far from tourist bustle, the restaurant is popular with Marseille locals – known as Marseillais – for its stripped-down and contemporary design and obviously its plates of marine inclinations. Rivalling its natural décor, this semi-gastronomic Mediterranean bistro offers a range of products from the sea: fish soup, seabass filet en croûte with honeyed preserved monkfish liver, grilled calamari served with eggplant caviar and caramelised peppers… Lovers of surf and turf will indulge in the house special, the veal tartare with oysters. Everything is super fresh as the menu changes every day, depending on the fish and crustacean catches sourced… only a few metres away on that same Marseille harbour.

However, its interior design really does stand out: Nhow actually pays tribute to all aspects of the spirit of Marseille, with shoals of sardines in-lieu of a chandelier above the Sky Bar, a lobby area adorned with a fresco depicting local personalities, rooms painted in yellow and white tones, inspired by beach huts… The Mediterranean is as present in the decoration choices as in the landscape, since most rooms offer private balconies with sea view and, in the distance, the Château d'If and Frioul islands. content.title: AM par Alexandre Mazzia, pure creativity

introduction.small: In his Michelin-starred restaurant, Alexandre Mazzia has put together a colourful and flavourful gastronomical journey like no other.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: AM par Alexandre Mazzia, pure creativity

paragraphs.text:
He learnt the ropes with Pierre Hermé, Alain Passard and Michel Bras among others, then opened his own restaurant in the very chic 8th district of Marseille. Starting as a pastry chef, Alexandre Mazzia moved up and fears nothing. At AM, you will find no menu, but blind tastings. A dozen dishes will go by before your eyes, with sheer creativity in the making. For instance, seafood is sublimated by a few delicate Asian influences. Unexpected pairings do not worry the chef, as signalled by his signature dishes: flower crispbread with harissa-strawberry condiments. Alternatively, you may be tempted by the langoustine with dates and broccoli in grilled sesame, Ladour salmon with pineapple and oyster shell miso, or perhaps eel-chocolate, coffee-hibiscus and coffee-sweet potato-button mushroom desserts…
The 3-Michelin-starred restaurant's black front, stylish decoration, concrete walls and clear-wood tables all showcase a pared-down and efficient atmosphere, in which Alexandre Mazzia's cooking is truly given pride of place. A minimalist and elegant setting for a gastronomical journey that will undoubtedly surprise you!

Lights on the ceiling and low wooden furniture glimmer with floral and fringed lampshades, family portraits in vintage frames are hung on the blue walls, while lace doilies cover the rustic tables where candles slowly burn.
As for the unique menu, it celebrates fresh ingredients and changes regularly. For instance, you can try duck shepherd's pie with stir-fried girolle mushrooms, or wild sea bream ravioli in galangal-lemongrass and blood orange Thai broth. For dessert, indulge in a tarte tatin that will take you back in time with its shallot sauce. A succession of flavours to give you the impression of having lunch at your grandma's.

content.title: The delights of secrecy at Carry Nation

introduction.small: Discover one of the most secret bars in Marseille, Carry Nation, a tribute to prohibition and speakeasies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The delights of secrecy at Carry Nation

paragraphs.text:
When Kansas prohibited the sale of alcohol, Carrie (or Carry) Amelia Moore Nation adhered to the temperance movement and launched a fierce fight against bars that flouted the law. Thinking she embodied a sacred mission, she sacked the impious establishments to the sound of religious hymns sung by her 'sisters'.

Carry Nation opened in the 6th arrondissement of Marseille in 2011, among the precursors of new French speakeasies. Sheltered by stone vaults, this first urban winery invites you to provide an email address and phone number to know its exact location, kept secret by the managers Guillaume Ferroni and Luc Litschgi. With a specific code, you enter a clandestine bar where bootleggers are busy preparing cocktails dating to Prohibition. You will be able to taste – in moderation of course – excellent spirits from America, Asia, France, Canada, West Indies, Jamaica, Cuba… the whole world really. Back to the heart of this mysterious era when Al Capone reigned as the master of contraband.

content.title: The Phap Hoa Pagoda, a Buddhist temple in Marseille

introduction.small: The biggest Buddhist place of worship in the city, this pagoda, little known to Marseillais, offers a moment of meditation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Phap Hoa Pagoda, a Buddhist temple in Marseille

paragraphs.text:
In the northern part of the city, the Phap Hoa Pagoda, open to all who want to visit, was built in the 1990s by a Buddhist monk, Tchich Thien Dinh. Little-known to the residents themselves, the building is worth seeing, especially for its architectural beauty. You will be able to see two imposing Buddha statues from a distance, one lying on his side and the other covered with gilding-they dominate the view from their posts.

The temple is home to the mausoleum of its founder, as well as a spiritual school. A complete change of scenery awaits you on the first Sunday of every month during a vegetarian lunch organized by the Vietnamese community. You will be welcome to discover their customs. Set at a large table, you will savour specialties with wisdom such as spring rolls or a vegetable tofu stir fry, under the watchful eye of the pagoda's priestess.

content.title: Le Petit Nice, luxury in the heart of Marseille

introduction.small: Showcasing excellence and refinement Le Petit Nice will dazzle you with a five-star hotel and a gastronomic restaurant that was awarded three stars by the Michelin Guide.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Petit Nice, luxury in the heart of Marseille

paragraphs.text:
Le Petit Nice is part of the Relais & Châteaux hotel group, a guarantee of refinement and elegance. Halfway between sea and sky, this beautiful building is exposed out in the open, like a peninsula lapped by blue waters. A haven of peace and sweetness, it is only five minutes away from Marseille's city centre.

For three generations, the 5-star hotel has belonged to the family of Gérald Passedat. The living spaces, lit by the sun streaming through the large windows and dressed in the region's earthy colours, create a pure and warm atmosphere. The understated rooms, many of which are styled like lofts, are elegantly decorated and feature monumental works by Gérard Traquandi that celebrate nature.

Three-star Michelin chef since 2008, Gérald Passedat creates dishes that explore the abundance of ingredients proffered by the Mediterranean Sea and the region of Provence. More than 65 fish varieties pass through his kitchen, some modest, other forgotten, all magnified and carrying their intense flavours.
Known for his love of good produce, the chef showcases the region's best: brousse du rove goat's cheese, bottarga, beautiful sundrenched tomatoes, eggplants and many other wonders of nature, all delivered by select local producers with whom he shares the same vision.
Try out his "open flame" cuisine, delivering the most pronounced of flavours!

It is decorated in a palette of rust, ochre, and brown. Its touches of primitive art and contemporary furniture are particularly inviting.

Travellers from around the world come to be pampered by Catherine, a gentle, smiling woman who takes care of them comme à la maison (as if they were at home). The four rooms have a very warm and welcoming atmosphere, and incredible views of the wonders of the Mediterranean.

Away from the hubbub of the city centre, and with direct sea access by the cliff road, Catherine starts your day with a copious breakfast of homemade yogurts, pancakes, and scrambled eggs. Spend the rest of the day relaxing on the terrace, or in the pool, Jacuzzi carved into the rock face, and sauna. You will wonder how you ever lived without all this comfort and joie de vivre!

content.title: La Siest'In, dreamlike cuisine

introduction.small: An unusual place. Come for lunch…and stay for a nap.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Siest'In, dreamlike cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Rue Paradis, the Cantini museum, Place Castellane… this busy, office-filled neighbourhood was the perfect place to open this unique lunch-and-nap spot. Original and innovative, it has become a huge hit with hungry locals in need of a kip. The Siest'In provides a healthy lunch of well-balanced dishes, all nicely rounded off with a rejuvenating nap. The daily menu changes with the seasons: quiche with pumpkin, an assortment of fresh salads, sandwiches and tartines made with good organic bread. The delicious desserts are prepared on site by the pastry chef: chocolate chip muffins, chocolate cornflakes cakes, fruit tart, chestnut cream tiramisu, almond pie, cheesecake… It may be hard to make up your mind!

At La Siest'In, you recharge your phone battery while recharging your own battery. After lunch, settle in for a nap in a bed, hammock, or recliner in one of the six individual cabins, each decorated with the image of a continent in warm, soothing shades. Then, back to the grind, refreshed and revitalised.

content.title: Les Halles de la Major, looking for local food

introduction.small: A concept place, with a warm and friendly atmosphere ideal for a uniquely unusual lunch, bringing out the best of Marseille and Provence into the Halles de la Major.

Gastronomy is the total focus under these two impressive and historically classified vaults. Tucked away under the immense Voûtes de la Major, Les Halles de la Major faces the sea in a majestic setting in the Joliette district. The unique concept makes for a convivial and engaging place, dedicated to the finest in of Provençal food.

Stepping into Les Halles de la Major is like entering a shrine to fine food. Everywhere you look, a blend of industrial and natural materials make the place exceptionally cosy. The stalls are islands, with large tables and wooden and leather stools, different coloured metal chairs, copper mobiles on the ceilings, cotton and linen hangings on the walls…

After you have finished your shopping, it is time to sit and eat. Eleven artisans – an oyster man, butcher, baker, greengrocer, Italian deli, cheese and wine sellers, and more besides – offer tapas, grilled fish, seafood platters, Italian delicacies, and other delicious dishes, all delivered by smiling and friendly servers.

Take full advantage of the pool, a relaxing treatment in the beautiful spa, or a game of golf or tennis.

Chef Christophe Bacquié's triple-Michelin-starred restaurant, meanwhile, is a jewel. and his take on fine Mediterranean cuisine is unique and masterful.

content.title: La Cantinetta, an “Italian” in Marseille

introduction.small: With a reputation second to none, this is the go-to place for lovers of authentic Italian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cantinetta, an “Italian” in Marseille

paragraphs.text:
Stéphanie and Pierre-Antoine opened La Cantinetta in 2006, near the music conservatory and the picturesque Cours Julien. This Italian restaurant has a friendly atmosphere that is constantly renewing itself hence its success with Marseillais regulars and newcomers alike. In the all-wood interior or on the lush terrace, an eclectic crowd comes to enjoy delicious dishes, prepared by two experienced Italian chefs, Luigi and Julio. La Cantinetta owes its success to Stéphanie and Pierre-Antoine's extensive travels, during which they have come to know all the best Italian artisanal suppliers.

Meats and cheeses, selected from the most famous Italian sources, take on their full dimensions, accompanied by tasty wines from Italy's best wineries. For starters, try the grilled and marinated vegetables served with Parma ham, or the burrata pugliese. As the pièce de résistance, enjoy the risotto or linguine alle vongole. Last but not least, end this culinary journey on a high with the swoon-worthy homemade tiramisu …

Coming to La Cantinetta is about enjoying Italian haute cuisine at its best and at incredibly reasonable prices. A must!

content.title: InterContinental Marseille Hôtel-Dieu, retro elegance

introduction.small: Panoramic views, top-chef dining, exceptional service, all wrapped up in a grandiose 18th century building.

The outer elegance of the Hôtel Dieu is echoed in the refinement of the lobby, the restaurants of Michelin-starred chef Lionel Levy – which include the Le Capian bar, the Les Fenêtres brasserie, and the Michelin-starred fine dining restaurant Alcyone – and the 194 beautifully decorated rooms and suites, 72 of which offer panoramic views of the Old Port, with private terraces overlooking the heart of the city. The luxury amenities will satisfy even the most demanding clients.

The rooms reflect the historic character of the Hôtel-Dieu building, with retro-styled décor, reinterpreted in more contemporary codes. The wide openings onto the bathrooms make the rooms bright and serene. As for the service, it is nothing short of impeccable.

Guests of the hotel will have a chance to benefit from the architect's original, well-thought-out structures, including a 40-seat cinema, jogging track, outdoor pool, tennis court in the park, and auditorium on the outstanding ninth-floor terrace. content.title: Between the Cité radieuse and the MAMO, Modern Art with a local twist

introduction.small: In 1952, Le Corbusier created a new way of living. The artist Ora-ïto has added a contemporary art space.

The architect and theorist Le Corbusier is the father of the Modulor, a stylized human figure intended to serve as a yardstick in all parts of a building. In the aftermath of the Second World War, he designed "housing units" and, in 1952, created the Cité radieuse - the "Radiant City" of Marseille. The concrete building on stilts contains nearly 340 homes entirely focused on functionality. Le Corbusier's building was criticised and ultimately rejected by part of the population, but it was nevertheless listed as a historical monument in 1986, in recognition of its ground-breaking innovations. Today, although it is still home to many families, there are also social spaces located on different rues, which usually means 'streets' in French but here refers to floors. The third and fourth floors have a vintage hotel, bar, and restaurant, and offer outstanding views of the city and MAMO, a space for artistic creation.

Created by the young designer Ora-ïto, the visionary spirit of Le Corbusier reigns at MAMO, which stands for 'Marseille Modulor'.

A historic monument since 1906, it can accommodate 3,000 people. It is a Marseille must-see for its breath-taking view of the sea and the latest developments in the Joliette area, with its new docks, halls and the Mucem.

Before climbing the stairs to enter the building, you pass through gates decorated with bronze medallions displaying allegorical dance and music motifs. The many symbols make you want to push open the door, revealing painted and sculpted frieze panels evoking Greek dance and theatre. The staircase takes you to the lobby, adorned with symmetrical mirrors that reflect the lights of the peristyle from the large bay windows. The hall seats 1,800 and recalls the spirit of Italian theatres, with its main floor divided into three distinct parts, and its balconies and boxes. Located 37km from Marseille city centre, the Domaine de la Bégude is a place oozing with history and poetry. Perched 400m above sea level, the vast 500-hectares property – including 17 hectares of vineyards – faces the sea and is swept by the mistral wind. It belongs to the Tari family, who are committed to working sustainably both in the production of their AOC Bandol wine and their land management – they grow some of the best organic produce in France.

Built on the site of a medieval manor, the estate added a vineyard, olive grove, and winery in the 18th century. The cellar is a 7th century chapel. In 1996, Guillaume and Soledad Tari reawakened this sleeping beauty, reopening the farm and restoring the older buildings. The Domaine de la Bégude is a magical destination and the perfect place for nature lovers. It offers special events, quad outings, walks, wine initiations, and visits to the winery and olive grove.

You will live a moment out of time, sleeping in the gorgeous guest rooms and sampling Sabine's locavore cuisine wild boars, partridges, pheasants, woodcocks, and completely organic produce. content.title: Les Terrasses and Les Voûtes: two new shopping hotspots

Open for several years now, Les Terrasses du Port proposes a new way of consuming in the Phocaean city.

Open to the sea, the new mall has become a place of life and exchange. The completely renovated space in the Docks district mixes honey-coloured stone with contemporary materials like glass, steel, and iron. Part of a vast rejuvenation operation of the coastline, it has become a symbol of urban renewal in the district. Its 192 stores meet all shopping needs. The giant terrace and 260m promenade make it a great place to enjoy a bite to eat in the fresh sea breeze, and drift into daydreams of a thousand journeys around the world.

A kilometre further south on Quai de la Joliette is the Voûtes de La Major, a new retail space under the arcades of Marseille Cathedral where you will find shops and higher-end restaurants. At the foot of the Voûtes is a new landscaped promenade dedicated to leisure, culture, shopping, and eating.

content.title: Le Panier: the oldest part of Marseille

introduction.small: An authentic quartier of beautiful buildings, charming squares, and narrow streets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Panier: the oldest part of Marseille

paragraphs.text:
Le Panier, the oldest part of Marseille, is north of the Old Port, behind the Town Hall, and was created by the Greek colony of Massalia in 600 BCE.

A working-class district, this is traditionally where immigrants have first settled in Marseille. In recent years, renovations and the establishment of new cultural venues have made Le Panier a tourist area, popular with visitors seeking 'authenticity'. A stroll through the area is a return to the daily life of Marseille. Through the narrow streets that climb among old houses and administrative buildings, the joyful sounds of schoolyards fill the air. It is a paradise for photography fans, with the surroundings inspiring all kinds of creativity.

There's plenty to visit, too, such as 'La Vieille Charité', 17th-century hospital transformed into an archaeology museum focusing on African, Pacific, and indigenous American art.

Do not miss La Grande Savonnerie, 36 Grand-Rue, one of the few places where you can buy genuine 'Savon de Marseille', the city's famous soap. Many places with bars and restaurants provide a relaxing break between two visits.

content.title: Le Ventre de l'Architecte, authentic cuisine at Le Corbusier

introduction.small: Ingenious alliances, sometimes risqué, always felicitous. They have made the reputation of this gastronomic restaurant in the Cité radieuse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Ventre de l'Architecte, authentic cuisine at Le Corbusier

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the famous Cité Radieuse designed by Le Corbusier in the 1950s, is this surprising gourmet restaurant, named after the Peter Greenaway film, The Belly of an Architect. Decorated in white wood and grey marble, the dining room is intimate, relaxing, and most of all timeless. The terrace, with its exceptional view, resembles a ship's passage with its wooden bridge, 1930s iron chairs and tables inspired by Jean Prouvé's iconic Compass models.

This is an authentic place with authentic cuisine. A meal here puts you in the hands of talented chef Jérôme Caprin, who elegantly showcases local produce and innovative flavour combinations in a host of elegant dishes: an ode to fine dining. In the evening, the gourmet offerings may include roasted scallops with saffron potatoes and "burnt" leeks, eggplant caviar with cashews, zucchini, mint, Espelette pepper and honey, or a slow-cooked filet of bull with potatoes en gratin, truffle and pepper sauce. For dessert, honey-roasted butternut, light vanilla mousse and caramel ice cream will bring closure to a delightful meal.

content.title: Marseille's old port, the city's emblem

introduction.small: The city's story starts here, in this 26-century old port. Simply put, the very heart of Marseille.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marseille's old port, the city's emblem

paragraphs.text:
The oldest port of Marseille is also the historic heart of the city. Founded in antiquity, the port was the economic centre of the city until the mid-19th century, open to the trade and commerce arriving from across the Mediterranean Sea and the French colonies. A symbol of Marseille, the ancient winding streets of the Old Port district is dotted with art galleries, bars, and cultural centres. The countless renovations and refurbishments of recent years have breathed new life into the city as a whole. The impressive Saint-Jean and Saint-Nicolas forts, built in the Middle Ages to protect the harbour, the imposing 17th-century City Hall, and the Saint-Victor Abbey testify to a rich past, and today share space with glass and steel buildings, and sumptuous squares redesigned in a more contemporary spirit. The old town's nerve centre and an ideal starting point for all tourist routes, the Old Port has lost none of its original lustre. It remains as authentic as its fish market and various small restaurants where you can take a break from your visit and enjoy the typical atmosphere of the premises. This is a meeting place for many locals and without a doubt one of the most popular areas of the city.

content.title: Mucem, when the old ways answer to modernity

introduction.small: The Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations, a modern and poetic work of architecture, pays tribute to Euro-Mediterranean societies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mucem, when the old ways answer to modernity

paragraphs.text:
Created by the architect Rudy Ricciotti, this museum is dedicated to contemporary Euro-Mediterranean cultures. Spanning some 45,000 sqm, the Mucem brings together anthropology, history, archaeology, art history, and contemporary art. It has something for everyone, presenting a cultural, social, scientific, and political perspective on the civilisations that have shaped the Mediterranean world from prehistory to the present.

The Mucem is above all a poetic place, where the old meets the new across three different sites: the heart of the ensemble, J4, hosts the Gallery of the Mediterranean and a temporary exhibition hall. It is also home to a children's corner, an auditorium for the presentation of shows, concerts and film series, a bookshop, and a restaurant with a panoramic terrace. Fort Saint-Jean, completely restored and connected to J4 via a footbridge jutting out above the sea, offers visitors a stunning panorama. Stroll through the new Mediterranean garden and discover the Mucem's many popular arts and traditions collections. The Conservation and Resource Centre (CCR), in the district of La Belle de Mai, provides a unique opportunity to explore the full wealth of the Mucem's collections, including almost 250,000 artefacts, 130,000 paintings, prints and drawings, and 450,000 photographs.

content.title: Palais Longchamp, art and history in a listed building

introduction.small: The Natural History Museum and the Musée des Beaux Arts are housed in the magnificent Palais Longchamp park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palais Longchamp, art and history in a listed building

paragraphs.text:
We owe the Palais Longchamp to the architect Henri-Jacques Espérandieu, whose many Marseille landmarks include the Notre-Dame de la Garde basilica and the Marseille Cathedral. At its centre, aa lush park is home to a beautiful fountain depicting a young woman and her companions. The fountain is itself surrounded on either side by two large staircases that lead to the wings of the palace. On the right is the Natural History Museum, while the left houses the Musée des Beaux-Arts. The two sides are connected by a semi-circular colonnade.

The wonders of the Palais Longchamp go far beyond this single building. All around are extensive and beautiful gardens. The garden of the first plateau, inaugurated at the same time as the building, is a true 'jardin à la française'. The other, located below, is a beautiful recreation area. Until 1987, this was home to the zoological gardens of Marseille, with cages and other animal shelters still remaining there today.

content.title: Notre-Dame de la Garde: watching over Marseille

introduction.small: The Marseille Basilica is a place of pilgrimage, where your body and soul will make contact with the heavens.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Notre-Dame de la Garde: watching over Marseille

paragraphs.text:
From its perch 154m above the city, the hill of the Guard is the highest natural elevation in Marseille. A listed site since 1917, its Virgin and Child protect the city and its inhabitants.

Constructed on a limestone peak 149m above sea level, the basilica straddles the districts of Roucas Blanc and Vauban. Built by Protestant architect Henri Espérandieu, the Romano-Byzantine structure, also known as the ‘Good Mother', has two parts: a Roman-style crypt dug in the rock and a mosaic-decorated church. At the top stands the Virgin and Child. This monumental 11.2m-high building, designed by Eugene Lequesne, was crafted in gilded copper covered with gold leaves in the famous workshops of Christofle.

To visit the 'Good Mother', you either take the rather steep road lined with pine trees, or the funicular directly to the steps of the monument. The views are breath-taking. In 2013, another museum was added, offering fine collections of votive offerings and objects of worship.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Marseille
content.introduction: Marseille has a Mediterranean climate. The city enjoys bright sunshine most of the year, in particular owing to the mistral, a dry wind that sweeps across the region 93 days each year, on average. Marseille has the lowest rainfall of all French cities, with an average of only 59 days with precipitation each year. Winters are mild and damp, with an average temperature of 8°C (46°F) in January and February, while summers are hot and dry, with the mercury often rising above 30°C (86°F) in July and August.

airports.title: Marseille-Provence Airport
airports.description:
The Marseille-Provence International Airport is located in the suburb of Marignane in Bouches-du-Rhône, about 25km (16 miles) west of Marseille.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Marseille and back:
  • By car
    • Access via the A7 motorway.
    • Parking facilities are grouped into three categories: Eco (P3, P7 and P8), Classic (P5) and Premium (P1 and P6).
    • For Eco parking: EUR 4.50 for the first 15 minutes, EUR 4.60 for 15-30 minutes, and EUR 4.70 for 30-45 minutes, then EUR 0.10 for each additional 15 minutes to a total of 12 hours, and EUR 10.50 for 24 hours.
    • For Classic parking: EUR 5 for the first 15 minutes, EUR 5.20 for 15-30 minutes, and EUR 5.40 for 30-45 minutes, then EUR 0.20 for each additional 15 minutes to a total of 7 hours, EUR 0.10 per additional 15 minutes for between 7 and 12 hours of parking, and EUR 14 for 24 hours.
    • For Premium parking: EUR 6 for the first 15 minutes, EUR 6.20 for 15-30 minutes, and EUR 6.40 for 30-45 minutes, then EUR 0.20 for each additional 15 minutes to a total of 12 hours, and EUR 18 for 24 hours
    • Several counters operated by car rental companies are located in the open-air parking areas.
  • By bus
    • Bus line 91 connects the Marseille-Provence airport with Marseille-Saint-Charles train station, not far from the Vieux Port.
    • Buses usually depart every 30 minutes between 5.10 a.m. and 11:10 p.m. from the airport, and between 4:10 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. from Marseille-Saint-Charles station. The trip takes about 25 minutes each way.
    • Single tickets cost EUR 10 for adults, EUR 7 for passengers aged 12 to 25 and EUR 5 for children aged 6 to 11 (free for children under 5). A return ticket is EUR 16.
    • At the airport, tickets are purchased at Terminal 1, opposite the shuttle pick-up/drop-off location. The ticket office is open every day from 6:05 a.m. to 10:10 p.m.
    • In the city centre, tickets are purchased at the Saint-Charles train station ticket counters, which are open every day from 5:20 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.
  • By train
    • 72 TER regional train lines serve Marseille from the Vitrolles-Aéroport-Marseille-Provence train station between 6:24 a.m. and 10:03 p.m. Monday to Friday (46 trains run between 6:24 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Saturdays, and 44 between 6:24 a.m. and 10:03 p.m. on Sundays).
    • There are TER ticketing machines at both the station and the airport. One-way fares range from EUR 20 to EUR 30.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are located outside Terminal 1, and are available24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The fare to the city centre is about EUR 50 during the day and EUR 60 at night.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, currency exchange and banking as well as free Internet access (Wi-Fi) are available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)820 81 14 14 (EUR 0.12 per minute)
  • Website: https://www.marseille-airport.com/

Service Train + Air :
  • Passengers transferring to Paris airports (Orly and Charles de Gaulle) who have an Air France flight number should take their plane ticket to the Train + Air counter at Marseille-Saint-Charles station to collect their train ticket between 24 hours and 20 minutes before the train's departure.
  • You can find all the information you need at: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/resainfovol/avion_train/reservation_avion_train_tgvair_airfrance.htm?_ga=2.90023453.766556504.1625040436-1336359705.1605863373
  • Marseille-Saint-Charles train station is located in Square Narvik, 13232 Marseille. It is open between 4:30 a.m. and 1:05 a.m. every day. From the station, you can access:
    – public transport: metro (lines M1 and M2), intercity coaches (CarTreize LeCar), shuttles to Marseille Provence Airport, bus terminal (international Blablabus & Flixbus services) and night bus (line 521).
    – private transport: drop-off area, taxis, car hire companies, parking facilities, bike hire companies.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Marseille
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Marseille each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues across Marseille.

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Marseille, this anniversary is commemorated each year with a fireworks display and dance parties open to everyone at various venues throughout the city.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: Notre-Dame de la Garde is the site of a popular pilgrimage for the Feast of the Assumption, followed by a torchlight procession and mass on the evening.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 25: Christmas (national holiday)
events.description: In Marseille and the entire region of Provence, a centuries-old holiday tradition demands that Christmas Eve guests be offered 13 desserts after dinner (grapes, nougat, dates, etc.).

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Marseille, with families and friends celebrating the new year.
